params.text:
Are you much into metrics? Machine translation is. Metrics are used during training, reported as a system metric, employed to compare among two MT systems or two versions of the same one. And we need to live with them, so, let’s see how to get the control, know how to compute them, understand them and use them. 

 

Let’s take the following text in English: 

 

The EU operates comprehensive approval procedures that ensure new members are admitted only when they can demonstrate they will be able to play their part fully as members, namely by: 

Complying with all the EU's standards and rules.

Having the consent of the EU institutions and EU member states.

Having the consent of their citizens – as expressed through approval in their national parliaments or by referendum.

Membership criteria – Who can join?

The Treaty on the European Union states that any European country may apply for membership if it respects the democratic values of the EU and is committed to promoting them.

The first step is for the country to meet the key criteria for accession. 

These were mainly defined at the European Council in Copenhagen in 1993 and are hence referred to as 'Copenhagen criteria'. 

Countries wishing to join need to have:

Stable institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law, human rights and respect for and protection of minorities.

A functioning market economy and the capacity to cope with competition and market forces in the EU.

The ability to take on and implement effectively the obligations of membership, including adherence to the aims of political, economic and monetary union.

The EU also needs to be able to integrate new members.

 

Paste it into an empty document and save it as a txt file. As you can see, the text is made of individual sentences: no paragraphs, no fancy format, only sentences in plain text. We will refer to it as the source text. 

 

Now using MutNMT engines in the Translate section or any MT engines out there covering English and Spanish, paste the original text and translate it with at least two different engines. Paste the output of each engine into two different text files. We will refer to them as mtoutput-1 and mtoutput-2. 

 

Finally, copy and paste the following text in another text file document: 

 

La UE aplica procedimientos de aprobación exhaustivos que garantizan la admisión de los nuevos miembros únicamente cuando puedan demostrar que podrán desempeñar plenamente su papel como miembros, a saber:

Cumplir con todos los estándares y normas de la UE

Contar con el consentimiento de las instituciones de la UE y de los Estados miembros de la UE.

Tener el consentimiento de sus ciudadanos, expresado mediante la aprobación en sus parlamentos nacionales o por referéndum.

Criterios de membresía — ¿Quién puede unirse?

El Tratado de la Unión Europea establece que cualquier país europeo puede solicitar la adhesión si respeta los valores democráticos de la UE y se compromete a promoverlos.

El primer paso consiste en que el país cumpla los criterios clave para la adhesión. 

Estos se definieron principalmente en el Consejo Europeo de Copenhague de 1993 y, por lo tanto, se denominan los «criterios de Copenhague». 

Los países que deseen unirse deben tener:

Instituciones estables que garanticen la democracia, el Estado de Derecho, los derechos humanos y el respeto y la protección de las minorías.

Una economía de mercado que funcione y la capacidad de hacer frente a la competencia y a las fuerzas del mercado en la UE.

La capacidad de asumir y aplicar eficazmente las obligaciones de la adhesión, incluida la adhesión a los objetivos de la unión política, económica y monetaria.

La UE también debe poder integrar a nuevos miembros.

 

This last text corresponds to a professional translation of the first document. We will refer to it as the reference text. Again, in your txt document, there will be sentences and sentence 1 from the reference text will be a professional translation from sentence 1 in the source text.  

 

We are now going to use MutNMT to get automatic metrics comparing the machine translated outputs to the reference translation. So, please, access MutNMT (ask your tutor to provide a link). To get acquainted with MutNMT’s way of evaluating, please take Nile’s tour on the MutNMT section called Evaluate. She will remind you about the type of texts that we just saw and introduce you to some of the metrics.

 

Once done, add the original, the two MT outputs and the reference translation to the corresponding fields in MutNMT and click on Evaluate. After processing the files, you will be able to see how each of the two MT outputs compare to the reference translation through the output automatic metrics BLEU, ChrF3 and TER. Please, take a piece of paper and write down the scores to fill in the following table:

params.text: These scores are computed at document level, taking into account all the sentences in the document. A detailed view of how each sentence contributed to get these scores is drawn in the chart below the scores. You can see their sentence numbers and their individual BLEU and TER scores. And if you scroll down you will be able to see the actual MT output sentence paired with both the original and the reference. Note the number of the sentence that did best and worst according to the scores and look it up by its sentence number at the bottom section. Take a piece of paper, copy the table and write down the details of the sentences scoring the worst and best BLEUs:
